posts.name: Harlockit
posts.cooked:
Can you please improve/update the Signal app so the current chat group can have far more than 150 members with admin control? My work place heavily depend on Signal app and I have far more than 150 members who need to join the new chat group that I created.

Thank you

Beta testing the new GV2 groups: Big Signal group with as many volunteering forum members as possible?

It’s a technical limitation of the way we send messages (your device encrypts and sends one message to every other device in the group). We’re actively working on ways to improve this and allow for much larger groups.

It’s actively being worked on here’s a post from the iOS developer.

link_counts.title: Beta testing the new GV2 groups: Big Signal group with as many volunteering forum members as possible?

posts.name: Harlockit
posts.cooked: Thank you very much for your quick response!! We desperately await for this new update to include much larger number of members… Thank you so much for making this great extremely useful app!!!

posts.name: Kp9001
posts.cooked: In the meantime, you might want to check out the matrix network as an alternative for very large groups. It is a messaging network supporting multiple clients. It uses the same fundamental encryption protocol as signal, but it uses group keys for groups rather than pairwise encryption, so it’s able to handle much larger groups efficiently. Element is the most popular client for it, if you’d like to check it out.

kp9001:

It uses the same fundamental encryption protocol

Can you please elaborate on this?
I don’t know the details of both protocols, but it’s new to me that they are the same…

posts.name: Kp9001
posts.cooked: Matrix uses olm for encryption, which is an implementation of the double ratchet algorithm developed for signal. This means the key exchanges in both protocols is fundamentally the same, and they both achieve perfect forward security in the same way. The encryption itself is based on Curve25519 in both cases. The major difference that I’m aware of is how they handle group chats.

posts.name: Harlockit
posts.cooked:
Thank you for your information.

But I have no clue what that is. I looked thru IOS app store and couldn’t find it. I’m not technically well versed. I think it’s too much to constantly change messenger app for an entire group though. We used groupchat before and then switched to Signal due to some security concerns. I hope Signal comes out with a new update very soon so we dont’ have to contantly switch to a new messenger app because Signal is by far the most simple and the best one in my opinion.

Thank you

posts.name: Kp9001
posts.cooked:
Here is what you want to look for to use on the apple app store: Element (iOS) | Matrix.org

Element is also available on android and desktop, and like signal, it will sync across platforms. If you use the element app, the process is basically as simple as any other mainstream messaging app.

Anyway, it’s understandable that switching is a hassle. I just wanted to share with you what I think is the best alternative that is currently available, in case a group with >150 people was necessary for you right now. Best of luck to you either way!
Using the same algorithms doesn’t mean it’s the same protocol. Maybe you meant to say algorithms instead of protocol. But now I understand what you were saying.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
The hard limit in Signal Android is now 1000 members (+ yourself); 150 (+ yourself) is just a recommendation (because of the performance implications of high member counts, which are being worked on, as noted above). Both numbers are still controlled by remote feature flags, though, so they can change at any time:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

Add feature flag driven group recommended size and hard size limits.

committed 08:56PM - 22 Oct 20 UTC
alan-signal
+245 -53

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked: We’re moving to a much higher hard limit. However, users will still be notified at 150 members that the experience isn’t going to be super-great. We’re working on it, but it currently can take a while to send a message in a group with hundreds of people.

greyson-signal:

We’re moving to a much higher hard limit.

All signs point to Signal becoming more of a slack/discord/matrix competitor.

  1. Larger group size limit
  2. Group voice calls
  3. Usernames

Good stuff!

Just wondering. In group version 1 on my phone the same message is encrypted with each group members devices key and send to those devices via Signal server. For example if there are 3 users each with 3 devices phone and desktop and laptop in a group, each my message has to be encrypted 9 times and send to Signal server. Small groups are not a problem, but large groups are. Is this one-message-to-be-encrypted-multiple-times in place with group version 2? E.g. 1000 users each having phone, device and laptop. My message that is send to group, is it still going to be encrypted 3000-times on my phone? Specially on old and slow Androd 4.4 phones, this can take a lot of time. And in the time message is send a lot of users may send additional messages and if not fast enough processed all of the history may look pretty non-historical.

shellSignal:

Is this one-message-to-be-encrypted-multiple-times in place with group version 2 ? E.g. 1000 users each having phone, device and laptop. My message that is send to group, is it still going to be encrypted 3000-times on my phone?

As far as I know, this has not changed.

greyson-signal:

it currently can take a while to send a message in a group with hundreds of people

Sorry for repeating myself over and over again, but I’m still hoping for an answer addressing my related question/problem which I raised in all beta feedback topics from v4.72 on:

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.72 release

Unfortunately, on my test device (Moto G1, Android 4.4.4, low mem device), the performance of the test GV2 group renders it plain unusable I switched on plane mode (= no internet connection) for a couple of days, and now that Signal is catching up, I can see the (hundreds of) messages, which have been written in the mean time, dropping in one by one every 5 seconds or so:
https://debuglogs.org/2343593905112950fef20157b83e74392b2b3d8b22e3d9ed36fcbdbfda09cb3e

[…]

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.74 release

Are there going to be performance improvements for “large” groups (10+) on low-mem devices? I posted several logs (which didn’t seem to have gotten any attention) in the 4.73 beta topic, because currently, for me the performance renders Signal useless for groups of more than 5-10 people.

I’m sure it all boils down to many linked devices in that group, but I stopped participating in the test group because it ended up getting messages (about 1 per minute) that had been sent 2 weeks ago -.-

link_counts.title: Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.72 release
Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.74 release
New messages and notifications really slow to come in

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked:
We’ve seen perf problems similar to yours trickle in over the last few months, but the problem is that I can’t reproduce any of them :( There are cases where two people with the same device are in the same group, and one person takes 5 seconds to open a conversation whereas it’s instant for the other. The only goodnews is that it doesn’t seem widespread. But it’s still a big problem.

My plan is to do some work to better instrument what’s happening. Right now the logs aren’t providing us the level of granularity we need. When I do that, I may reach out to you to as an early tester :)

link_counts.title: New messages and notifications really slow to come in
Handset / Android message retrieval extremely slow
